content.$t: Kensington Remembers: Using Digital Scholarship to Conduct and Document Fieldwork on Urban Vernacular Memory

gs$cell.inputValue: Kensington Remembers: Using Digital Scholarship to Conduct and Document Fieldwork on Urban Vernacular Memory
gs$cell.$t: Kensington Remembers: Using Digital Scholarship to Conduct and Document Fieldwork on Urban Vernacular Memory

content.$t:
Kensington Remembers (https://kensingtonremembers.org) is a digital project that is based on 2 years of multimodal ethnographic fieldwork (Pink, 2011; Collins et al, 2017) in North Philadelphia, where I have photographed, documented, and collected data on vernacular memorials.  In a city full of official memory—monumentalized in architecture, murals, museums, parks, site markers, and statuary, all produced and sustained thanks to the institutional resources of cultural elites—Kensington and the other neighborhoods of North Philadelphia sustain a rich tradition of “grassroots” or vernacular memory (Magry and Cortez-Contrero, 2011).  These take a variety of forms—makeshift shrines, ghost bikes, murals, graffiti, and other material performances of mourning—all produced by ordinary people using whatever skills and materials they have to public perform private emotions.  No official record or documentation of these sites of vernacular memory exists, and indeed without official institutional support they are vulnerable to the vicissitudes of the weather, the caprice of neighbors and vandals, and to the ambitions of developers who are rapidly destroying the neighborhood niches which these sites of memory occupy.

Partly in order to document and preserve these sites of vernacular memory, and partly to document and make public the ongoing fieldwork process, Kensington Remembers features a digital storymap (Jayawardene, 2020; Mocnik and Fairbaim, 2018; Powell, 2010). Digital story mapping permits the combination of location data, photography, and field notes to tell the stories of the memorials and those whose losses they mourn. This presentation will showcase the Kensington Remembers site, explain the production process, and advocate for the further use of digital scholarship to conduct and document place-based, place-making ethnographic work.

content.$t:
My project demonstrates that digital humanities tools can be leveraged by museum professionals and scholars to get a better understanding of museum collections. I focused on the Carnegie Museum of Art, as they publicly released collections records for all of their accessioned artworks. As their mission statement speaks to collecting global art that engages diverse audiences, I thought it would be interesting to examine their collections data to get a sense of how global their collection is. Using Tableau and OpenRefine, I explored this question through four facets: mapping the artists' nationalities, looking at acquisition trends by nationality, determining which items are on view by artist nationality, and interrogating the idea of nationality itself. 

I believe this could be a valuable addition to Keystone DH 2021 because this is a straightforward project completed with relatively accessible and easy-to-learn tools that many museums or researchers could model in order to get a better understanding of what and who comprises a collection. 

Further, I provided detailed descriptions of my data cleaning and data visualization process. Transparency within data work is important as it helps people better understand the results. I hope that providing such detail will help future researchers who might want to model this project.

The website and findings I would present can be found here: https://savannahlake.github.io/dh201/index.html

content.$t: Mapping Environmental Injustice: Telling the Story of Local Environmental Justice History Through Social, Economic, and Environmental Spatial Data

gs$cell.inputValue: Mapping Environmental Injustice: Telling the Story of Local Environmental Justice History Through Social, Economic, and Environmental Spatial Data
gs$cell.$t: Mapping Environmental Injustice: Telling the Story of Local Environmental Justice History Through Social, Economic, and Environmental Spatial Data

content.$t:
Although NYC OpenData provides access to countless public data sets and portal tools to visualize data about the urban demographics and built environment of NYC, there is no contextualization that facilitates a critical understanding of this quantitative data. Following Miriam Posner's invitation in “What’s Next” in the Debates in the Digital Humanities 2016, I am creating an alternate data visualization tool that centers critical inquiry of its construction and ideological ends alongside examining and contextualizing local urban environmental data. The relationship between location and environmental conditions reveals disparities across the boroughs of NYC which, with the additional analysis of social and economic status of these communities, presents evidence of the structures that engender these harmful inequities. In my work on investigating environmental injustice in NYC, I follow the spirit of DH to utilize digital tools to not only expand my humanistic inquiry into the history of local environmental politics, but to also connect historical and social awareness to the environmental datasets provided by NYC agencies.
 
In my proposed presentation, I will showcase the web tool which weaves narrative onto an interactive map about environmental conditions in NYC communities. I additionally intend to recount and reflect on the methodology and deployment of this tool. The larger research questions that have arisen as a result of pursuing this DH project include: What stories are there to be told in the data? What are the affordances and dis-affordances in using mapping as a tool in telling the narrative? How will sustainable computing practices be folded into a digital tool about environmental justice? This work pays special attention to thinking about public facing DH projects and hopes to inform and be used by not just general users but policymakers, activists, organizations, and DH scholars invested in environmental justice conversations.

content.$t: Video Production in the Writing Classroom and its Adaptability across Disciplines

gs$cell.inputValue: Video Production in the Writing Classroom and its Adaptability across Disciplines
gs$cell.$t: Video Production in the Writing Classroom and its Adaptability across Disciplines

content.$t: Video has become an essential means of everyday communication in academic and non-academic situations alike. If you’ve Googled a poem title, browsed through a popular science website like Scientific American, or searched “how do I (fill in the blank),” you’ve probably encountered, and maybe even clicked on, a relevant video. As a result, video production projects, once seen as unusual and experimental, are becoming increasingly accepted as an effective way to practice, evaluate, and present writing in the classroom. Colleges across the country are expanding their resources to accommodate this shift, and some departments have even added mandatory multimodal components to their courses. In this presentation, I examine three successful, genre-based video production assignments taught in the undergraduate writing classroom across three disciplines: literature, business, and biology. I will trace how these distinct assignments build on the same core principles, demonstrating the adaptability of the video project to various pedagogical situations. I will also articulate how these projects introduce students to real-world research, writing, and presentation situations they will likely encounter in their lives and careers, and offer suggestions for how such assignments can be adapted to remote learning situations. My ultimate goal in this presentation is to demonstrate the practicality of such assignments and enable other teachers to adapt them to their own syllabi. Though they may seem daunting at first, video assignments can be quite accessible and engaging, and they expose students to a variety of writing and communication situations that more traditional projects cannot.

content.$t: Hypermedia as Pedagogy: Introducing the Interactive Directory of Educational Memepages

gs$cell.inputValue: Hypermedia as Pedagogy: Introducing the Interactive Directory of Educational Memepages
gs$cell.$t: Hypermedia as Pedagogy: Introducing the Interactive Directory of Educational Memepages

content.$t: Over the past two decades, Internet memes have transformed from juvenile cat jokes into a powerful cultural, artistic, and political force. Memes are thus understood by the general public as both trivial humorous minutiae and a chaotic and uncontrollable influence beyond lay comprehension. However, memes are also a part of the everyday lives of millions of young people, and their influence is neither necessarily trivial, nor necessarily harmful. Memes also do not necessarily have to align with the commonly held “dumbing down” narrative regarding mass-media and popular culture. In fact, there is a massive subculture of academic meme groups and pages on Facebook that do the exact opposite: mixing memes with historical, scientific, literary, philosophical, and other intellectual content into a vibrant new pedagogical and communicative form. In these communities, memes connect young students, serious academics, and earnest hobbyists into densely interconnected communities which function as hubs for collaboration, community education, and intellectual exploration.

content.$t: Reading Epigraphy in the Digital Era

gs$cell.inputValue: Reading Epigraphy in the Digital Era
gs$cell.$t: Reading Epigraphy in the Digital Era

content.$t: With hindsight, scholars have usually regarded the An Lushan Rebellion (755–763) as a watershed moment in the history of the Tang dynasty (618–907), triggering its slow but sure decline. From this angle, numerous studies have been carried out on the Rebellion, its historical background, and its impact on Chinese history. But except for accounts describing the experiences of the emperors, several generals, and a few cultural heroes or villains carefully constructed in official historical records, we have little in the way of personal testimony of the Rebellion.

content.$t: Who is Watson?  A Stylistic Exploration of Narrative Voice

gs$cell.inputValue: Who is Watson?  A Stylistic Exploration of Narrative Voice
gs$cell.$t: Who is Watson?  A Stylistic Exploration of Narrative Voice

content.$t:
The non-protagonist narrator (sometimes called “The Watson”) is a standard trope in detective fiction “His job is to observe and record all the facts, and to fail completely to perceive their significance. Thereby he gives the reader all the necessary information, and he affords [the Great Detective] the opportunity to expound its bearing on the case.” (Freeman, 1941).  R. Austin Freeman, among many other authors, uses a Watson extensively, but (unusually) has many different Watsons, sometimes in the course of a single book.  As with epistolary novels, this raises the question of how different the narrative voices and styles are.

We present the results of a study of different Watsons.  We partitioned several Thorndyke novels into chapters and used the JGAAP tool to classify the chapters by narrator.  We analyze the differences between first- and third-person narrators within this genre (which is surprisingly little) and the differences between both individual narrators and narrative types.   For brevity, we report here only the most complex case:  The novel Pontifex, Son, and Thorndyke contains 18 chapters, eight by “Gray,” ten by “Jervis”, intermixed in a complex fashion.  On the basis of simple feature sets such as the fifty most common words, we were able to correctly identify the narrator of 17/18 chapters.

We therefore conclude that stylometric techniques can separate narrative voices in a multi-narrative work.  This opens the doors to several additional technological questions, among them our ability to profile narrators, and also the ability of skilled writers to assume varying personae for deceptive purposes.

content.$t: On Resisting the Imperative to Visualize

gs$cell.inputValue: On Resisting the Imperative to Visualize
gs$cell.$t: On Resisting the Imperative to Visualize

content.$t:
This paper posits DH as the experimental grounds on which new research questions are asked, new research designs are configurated, and new research identities are developed. More pointedly, it questions DH on its penchant for visualizations as a mode of inquiry and presentation of knowledge. 

To demonstrate the possibilities of the DH inquiry goes beyond graphs and screen-based creations, the paper takes the digital work of two scholars/artists who advance humanities knowledge by exploring a wide range of perception modalities: Andrien Segal, a California-based artis who uses data collected from the natural world (tree rings, ice cores, layers of sedimentation) and draws on theories of emotion and perception to synthesize information and create an intently human experience and Hannah Davis, a generative musician and researcher based in New York City whose data sonification work transposes text (and textual analysis) into musical compositions trying to preserve the original emotional tone and create melodies and musical stories from datasets and historical sound samples representing diverse experiences and worldviews.

The paper concludes with a few suggestions about the importance to train imagination and to include in the DH curriculum a variety of sites, spaces, datatypes, and formats though which to produce and express new knowledge.

content.$t: "Worthy Arguers": Non-Adversarial Approaches in Social Media Forums

gs$cell.inputValue: "Worthy Arguers": Non-Adversarial Approaches in Social Media Forums
gs$cell.$t: "Worthy Arguers": Non-Adversarial Approaches in Social Media Forums

content.$t:
In Daniel Cohen’s Ted Talk “For Argument’s Sake,” he invites the audience to consider how to reject the argument-as-war model in pursuit of arguments that prioritize experiencing “cognitive gain” over merely winning a debate.  To do so, he suggests we seek to become “worthy arguers” by considering negotiation, collaboration, and deliberation as rhetorical ideals.  Many of our students seek to become worthy arguers—the kind who can weigh competing claims, consider complex evidence, and arrive at reasonable conclusions that support new action rather than reinforce firmly-held positions. Yet they often have difficulty locating and following useful models for arguing ethically.  This paper seeks to offer a pedagogical alternative to traditional argument writing assignments that unintentionally may promote further participation in and adherence to the “argument culture,” to borrow Deborah Tannen’s term.  
Each semester, I share Cohen’s Ted Talk with my students as I introduce them to non-adversarial approaches to argumentation including Rogerian rhetoric, listening rhetoric, and collaborative argumentation.  To learn about these approaches, my students read various works by Carl Rogers, Krista Ratcliffe, Josina Makau and Debian Marty, and Brian Jackson and Jon Wallin, among others.  To practice these non-adversarial approaches, I then ask my students to analyze conversations and debates on social media comment threads related to contemporary issues.  Within these forums, students quickly identify the “monstrous” quality of the argument-as-war model as described by Cohen; they also intuitively recognize facets of Deborah Tannen’s “argument culture” in their own academic and personal lives, as well.  By practicing the “back-and-forthness of rhetoric” that Jackson and Wallin detail in their seminal study, students can better recognize and avoid the pitfalls of adversarial argumentation, thereby honing their skills, instead, in deliberative argumentation.

gs$cell.inputValue:
In Daniel Cohen’s Ted Talk “For Argument’s Sake,” he invites the audience to consider how to reject the argument-as-war model in pursuit of arguments that prioritize experiencing “cognitive gain” over merely winning a debate.  To do so, he suggests we seek to become “worthy arguers” by considering negotiation, collaboration, and deliberation as rhetorical ideals.  Many of our students seek to become worthy arguers—the kind who can weigh competing claims, consider complex evidence, and arrive at reasonable conclusions that support new action rather than reinforce firmly-held positions. Yet they often have difficulty locating and following useful models for arguing ethically. content.$t: Investigating Methods of Computational Rhetorical Assessment

gs$cell.inputValue: Investigating Methods of Computational Rhetorical Assessment
gs$cell.$t: Investigating Methods of Computational Rhetorical Assessment

content.$t:
Digital tools have played an increasingly important role in the grading of student writing. Yet, while automated evaluation software like the ETS E-rater® is acclaimed by educational measurement specialists for its reliability and validity (Deane, 2014), many composition scholars (Huot, 2002; Coxwell-Teague & Lunsford, 2014) worry such systems fail to consider guiding rhetorical principles of assessment—and thus, fail to accurately measure students’ rhetorical skills. This is especially important because of the far-reaching impacts of assessment, from end-of-term grades and course placement to pedagogical decisions and writing program evaluation. 

Still, automated writing evaluation reveals technology’s potential to inform assessment-based pedagogical challenges, specifically regarding speed, generalizability, and the output of quantifiable metrics (Alder-Kassner & O’Neill, 2010). Is there a way to leverage computer-based text analysis to develop more rhetorically informed methods of writing assessment? How could such methods be incorporated not into an AES system, but instead into localized, instructor-driven pedagogy? 

In my short paper, I will seek to answer these questions through a discussion of my ongoing research, which explores the utility of DocuScope—a digital rhetorical analysis tool developed at Carnegie Mellon University—in supporting writing assessment. My recent study evaluates DocuScope’s ability to identify meaningful patterns of rhetorical action in high-scoring student essays. I will walk through my research pipeline, highlighting the visualization tools available through DocuScope and additional methods I implemented to better isolate “clusters” of linguistic features indicative of rhetorical action. I will then discuss the value of such methods in first-year writing assessment; for example, instructors could share DocuScope’s output with students as formative feedback or as support in scoring traditional rubric categories. Further, I will discuss how this research may contribute more broadly to the field of Digital Humanities.

content.$t:
“Retelling, Teedyuscung” seeks to retell the story of a statue and Native American man attributed to the statue, Teedyuscung - a once feared and revered leader of the Lenni Lenape. This paper is supplemented by a digital tour of the statue and surrounding lands. 

This statue, entitled the Tedyuscung Statue, stands in Philadelphia’s Wissahickon Valley. The statue’s form and the story it narrates purports to represent Teedyuscung, the man, or his Lenni Lenape peoples in any meaningful way. This statue, and its interpretive wayside marker, instead, promotes the myth of the vanishing Indian. 

My work seeks to amend this story. I unravel this story by culling integral primary sources from Philadelphia’s Chestnut Hill Historical Society’s and the Germantown Historical Society’s archival collections, synthesizing these sources with secondary accounts of residents from Chestnut Hill and the surrounding neighborhoods in the Wissahickon Valley.  And, ultimately, I prove that the statue merely commemorates a Chestnut Hill folktale that places Teedyuscung as the focal actor. As Teedyuscung never stepped foot upon the rock or land in which this statue stands. And, indeed, an amendment to this statue and story it promotes, must be made.

content.$t: Object Networks in Literature and Art: Showcasing ThingStor.Org—A Material Culture Database

gs$cell.inputValue: Object Networks in Literature and Art: Showcasing ThingStor.Org—A Material Culture Database
gs$cell.$t: Object Networks in Literature and Art: Showcasing ThingStor.Org—A Material Culture Database

content.$t: An interdisciplinary team of graduate students and faculty from the University of Delaware will showcase ThingStor: A Material Culture Database for Finding Objects in 19th-Century Literature and Visual Art. The database originated with students encountering objects like “a “Bowie knife” or a “Lucifer” or a “carpet bag” when reading literary classics or viewing famous genre paintings produced in England and the United States during the nineteenth century. Questions, like What is this thing?, What does it do?, How popular was it?, found no easy answers when using generic research strategies, be it the quick check on Wikipedia or the targeted search in historical or literary databases. Prompted by this lack of access, an interdisciplinary group of graduate students, faculty, and librarians working in the Humanities at UD have now developed ThingStor.Org into a collaborative research project, with the goal to design a database that provides access, background, and a sense of scale of the way in which objects of all kinds circulate in and communicate across the literary and visual arts.

content.$t: Workshop: FairCopy: A Word Processor for the Digital Humanities

gs$cell.inputValue: Workshop: FairCopy: A Word Processor for the Digital Humanities
gs$cell.$t: Workshop: FairCopy: A Word Processor for the Digital Humanities

content.$t: FairCopy: A Word Processor for the Digital Humanities

gs$cell.inputValue: FairCopy: A Word Processor for the Digital Humanities
gs$cell.$t: FairCopy: A Word Processor for the Digital Humanities

content.$t:
FairCopy is a specialized word processor for studying manuscripts and historical texts. It gives scholars a desktop editing environment to create TEI encoded texts without writing XML code. In this workshop, we will demonstrate how to use FairCopy. We will then work in small groups with texts from the Library of Congress.

The Text Encoding Initiative (TEI) is an international consortium that publishes a set of guidelines for encoding digital representations of textual primary sources. In 2017, it was awarded the Antonio Zampolli Prize from the Alliance of Digital Humanities Organizations, reflecting its impact over the last 30 years on the digital humanities. The TEI Guidelines have been used by hundreds of scholarly projects and are an essential tool for researching, preserving, and disseminating cultural heritage world-wide.

And yet, despite its mission to provide a common vocabulary for describing texts, TEI faces problems of adoption and use in the wider scholarly community. While the basics of TEI XML encoding are simple enough, true fluency in TEI requires institutional support and commitment in the form of training, technical staff, IT infrastructure, and the time and commitment of the individual scholar. Many critical editing projects choose not to use TEI's guidelines because of these barriers.

FairCopy intervenes as a solution focused on the needs of the individual scholar and their students. It provides a complete user interface layer over the TEI Simple schema. Scholars can seamlessly import and export TEI XML documents. They can also bring in IIIF images of primary resources and link them to their transcriptions. 

FairCopy is desktop software and can work online or offline. We plan to offer it in English, Spanish, and French. FairCopy is in early access and is available for free at [www.faircopyeditor.com](www.faircopyeditor.com). FairCopy will be available commercially in Fall 2021.

content.$t: Workshop: Digital Commonplace Book Keeping: Developing Digital Methods for an Early-Modern Intellectual Technology

gs$cell.inputValue: Workshop: Digital Commonplace Book Keeping: Developing Digital Methods for an Early-Modern Intellectual Technology
gs$cell.$t: Workshop: Digital Commonplace Book Keeping: Developing Digital Methods for an Early-Modern Intellectual Technology

content.$t: Digital Commonplace Book Keeping: Developing Digital Methods for an Early-Modern Intellectual Technology

gs$cell.inputValue: Digital Commonplace Book Keeping: Developing Digital Methods for an Early-Modern Intellectual Technology
gs$cell.$t: Digital Commonplace Book Keeping: Developing Digital Methods for an Early-Modern Intellectual Technology

content.$t: How can commonplacing practices go digital and be integrated with other forms of digital writing? How can a conversation of commonplace books inform online note-taking, reflections, and other common practices in the humanities and social sciences? Early modern commonplace book practices endure for writers who gather and develop ideas. A commonplace book is composed with a long timeline of articulating, organizing, and revisiting thoughts, and many handwritten commonplace books include an index that facilitates returning to earlier work based on identified themes. This workshop will help participants reflect on the purposes of intellectual preparation and process writing in the humanities and social sciences so they can make more conscious choices about digital note-taking for reading, listening, and composing purposes. It includes suggestions for how to set up the submission and evaluation of note-taking assignments on learning management systems such as Canvas and discusses sustainable evaluation and grading practices for reflective assignments. We will consider how note-taking assignments can create more inclusive and fair conditions for participation in class, especially in online classrooms. This workshop will also include images of historical commonplace books from the special collections of Houghton Library at Harvard University.

It includes suggestions for how to set up the submission and evaluation of note-taking assignments on learning management systems such as Canvas and discusses sustainable evaluation and grading practices for reflective assignments. We will consider how note-taking assignments can create more inclusive and fair conditions for participation in class, especially in online classrooms. This workshop will also include images of historical commonplace books from the special collections of Houghton Library at Harvard University.

content.$t: Workshop: Creating & Sustaining Community Sourced DH Projects

gs$cell.inputValue: Workshop: Creating & Sustaining Community Sourced DH Projects
gs$cell.$t: Workshop: Creating & Sustaining Community Sourced DH Projects

content.$t: Creating & Sustaining Community Sourced DH Projects

gs$cell.inputValue: Creating & Sustaining Community Sourced DH Projects
gs$cell.$t: Creating & Sustaining Community Sourced DH Projects

content.$t:
This workshop will use a hands-on experience with the open-source software [Scripto for Omeka S](https://www.scripto.org) to frame a conversation about building and sustaining community-sourced projects. Scripto for Omeka S is a tool which works with the open-source software systems [Omeka S](https://omeka.org/s/) and [MediaWiki](https://www.mediawiki.org) to build projects which generate transcriptions, descriptions, and translations via community contribution. Scripto is the underlying architecture for the community transcription aspect of [The Papers of the War Department 1784-1800 (PWD)](https://wardepartmentpapers.org/), a digital humanities project which started at East Stroudsburg University in the mid 1990s. 
The workshop will include an opportunity for participants to experiment with using Scripto for Omeka S as users and to experience its administrative interface. There will also be a guided discussion of the practicalities of sustaining digital humanities projects as they evolve to meet new needs, technologies, and audiences. The conversation will also include the practical concerns which arise when creating, and changing, a community-sourced project. We will address the need to recognize and celebrate the communities which are connected to the original materials and those who are doing the work of creating these transcriptions/translations. 
The workshop leaders have experience with community-sourced projects through their work on Scripto and the PWD. Megan Brett is a doctoral candidate in the Department of History and Art History at George Mason University and is currently the project manager for Scripto and the PWD. Dr. Christopher Hamner is the principal investigator for Scripto and is the Editor in Chief of the PWD.

content.$t: Workshop: Enabling Scholarly Engagement with Library Collections Using a Data Layers Approach

gs$cell.inputValue: Workshop: Enabling Scholarly Engagement with Library Collections Using a Data Layers Approach
gs$cell.$t: Workshop: Enabling Scholarly Engagement with Library Collections Using a Data Layers Approach

content.$t: Enabling Scholarly Engagement with Library Collections Using a Data Layers Approach

gs$cell.inputValue: Enabling Scholarly Engagement with Library Collections Using a Data Layers Approach
gs$cell.$t: Enabling Scholarly Engagement with Library Collections Using a Data Layers Approach

content.$t:
In recent years, scholars, archivists, and librarians have expressed strong interest in the opportunities presented by collections as data approaches [1], but putting such approaches into practice is challenging.[2] There are many library data formats [3],  and accessing/using collections data at scale can be difficult. Simultaneously, librarians and archivists face difficulties making collections available in computable formats, facilitating collaborative and ongoing enrichment of that data, and curating enriched collections data.[4]
Our project, From Collection Records to Data Layers: A Critical Experiment in Collaborative Practice (or CaD@Pitt, an implementation grant of the larger “Collections as Data: Part to Whole” grant),[5] seeks to address many of these challenges by adopting a “data layer” mindset, which downplays the expectation for a single, non-interpretive, and exhaustive data model on one platform and emphasizes, instead, an interface made up of data from multiple sources, each with its own expectations of accuracy, consistency, and completeness, all of which must be well clear to the user. A “data layers” approach liberates data curation from the expectation of perfection and allows data to be enriched, augmented and interpreted incrementally over time. The use of flat files in a familiar format (CSV) also provides a practical and low-barrier entry point for scholars to create data layers based on their research priorities and to share that data.
In this workshop, the project team will demonstrate how academic librarians might go about making their catalog and/or digital repository metadata available to users for discovery and analysis using a data layers approach. Participants will learn about how this collections as data workflow was implemented in the CaD@Pitt project, discuss potential implementations at their local institution, and use the CaD@Pitt GitHub repository to transform and explore library metadata in a demo workflow.[6]

content.$t: Workshop: Reading at Scale: Hands On with the Distant Reader

gs$cell.inputValue: Workshop: Reading at Scale: Hands On with the Distant Reader
gs$cell.$t: Workshop: Reading at Scale: Hands On with the Distant Reader

content.$t: Reading at Scale: Hands On with the Distant Reader

gs$cell.inputValue: Reading at Scale: Hands On with the Distant Reader
gs$cell.$t: Reading at Scale: Hands On with the Distant Reader

content.$t: Many of us feel we are suffering from information overload, and through the use of the Distant Reader, this hands-on workshop facilitates activities to read large amounts of text. The Distant Reader is a tool for reading. It takes an arbitrary amount of text as input, does text mining and natural language processing against it, and outputs sets of structured data for in-depth analysis -- "reading". Intended for academics -- students, researchers, or scholars -- the Reader can consume and report on the whole of an undergraduate's reading list, the literature review of a researcher, or the totality of a genre for the humanist. The Distant Reader can literally consume, process, and report on hundreds, if not thousands, of journal articles or books. The Reader's output is affectionately called a "study carrel". It includes the original input data, the data transformed into plain text, a couple of narrative reports, many tab-delimited files, and a database file. Used in conjunction with either desktop and command-line tools, these files enable you to quickly and easily answer questions about your corpus. Example questions include: what is discussed in this corpus, how are things described, who is in the corpus, what places are mentioned, what are the overarching themes of the corpus, how are those themes related each other, which documents are exemplars, etc. Study carrels perform far beyond full text relevancy ranked indexing. In this workshop participants will be asked to assemble a small collection of PDF files, about a dozen items. Participants will compress the files into a single zip file, and submit the zip file to the Reader. The Reader will do its work and create a study carrel. Participants will then download their study carrel and use its contents to "read" their collection in new and interesting ways.

Intended for academics -- students, researchers, or scholars -- the Reader can consume and report on the whole of an undergraduate's reading list, the literature review of a researcher, or the totality of a genre for the humanist. The Distant Reader can literally consume, process, and report on hundreds, if not thousands, of journal articles or books. The Reader's output is affectionately called a "study carrel". It includes the original input data, the data transformed into plain text, a couple of narrative reports, many tab-delimited files, and a database file. Used in conjunction with either desktop and command-line tools, these files enable you to quickly and easily answer questions about your corpus. Example questions include: what is discussed in this corpus, how are things described, who is in the corpus, what places are mentioned, what are the overarching themes of the corpus, how are those themes related each other, which documents are exemplars, etc. Study carrels perform far beyond full text relevancy ranked indexing. In this workshop participants will be asked to assemble a small collection of PDF files, about a dozen items. Participants will compress the files into a single zip file, and submit the zip file to the Reader. The Reader will do its work and create a study carrel. Participants will then download their study carrel and use its contents to "read" their collection in new and interesting ways.

content.$t: “What can Black digital humanities be? Movements, Collectives, Principles”

gs$cell.inputValue: “What can Black digital humanities be? Movements, Collectives, Principles”
gs$cell.$t: “What can Black digital humanities be? Movements, Collectives, Principles”

content.$t:
Black digital humanities has come a long way. In the past decade, emerging and established Black DH practitioners have created new formations and communities, including NEH Summer Institutes (Nieves and Gallon), special journal issues (Johnson and Neal), The Digital Black Atlantic (Risam and Josephs), research centers (AADHUM and DigBlk), digital archives (DocNow), and a burgeoning canon of scholarship on contemporary Black digital life and culture (Bailey, Benjamin, Brock, Foreman, Nelson, Noble, Parham, Steele, and many more). The current state of the field builds on the towering legacies of projects such as, among others, the Project on the History of Black Writing (Graham et al) and e-Black Studies (Alkalimat). An open Google Doc created by the Colored Conventions Project in 2017 now links to more than 300 Black digital projects, events, and resources. And Black digital work thrives in the arts, museums, and racial justice movements. These achievements represent only a small fraction of the vibrant and visionary work in Black DH pushing into many fields and worlds. 

And yet these fields have blossomed in the years between the murders of Trayvon Martin and Breonna Taylor, Sandra Bland and George Floyd. It is a pattern of truth and reconciliation, the backlash of anti-Black racism and the advance of Black digital studies. 

In this talk we will share our collaborative and collective journeys. We each began in the early days of Black Twitter and the Colored Conventions Project, and played parts in the launch of AADHUM, Douglass Day, and DigBlk. We’ll share the questions that arose at each step about who, how, and why — about the all-important struggle to balance access to institutional resources with accountability to Black communities. Those questions point us to the principles that ground our work now, and where Black digital collective work might lead us next — such as the #BlackDigitalSyllabus.

content.$t: Towards a Phonological Algorithm of Old Chinese -- Introducing DIRECT (“Digital Intertextual Resonances in Early Chinese Texts”)

gs$cell.inputValue: Towards a Phonological Algorithm of Old Chinese -- Introducing DIRECT (“Digital Intertextual Resonances in Early Chinese Texts”)
gs$cell.$t: Towards a Phonological Algorithm of Old Chinese -- Introducing DIRECT (“Digital Intertextual Resonances in Early Chinese Texts”)

content.$t:
What’s a parallel passage in ancient Chinese texts? In this presentation, we will discuss the limitations of standard grapheme-based search algorithms found in most databases and search engines when dealing with a pre-modern language that does not rely on an alphabetic script or a syllabary. Chinese characters are often assumed to have a direct relationship with single words or morphemes, a view that would validate grapheme-based searches. However, actual writing practices are more complicated, in that they ultimately rely to a certain degree on phonetic components, especially during the vast shifts and standardizations the script underwent in the ancient period (c. 3rd century BCE to 220 CE).

Our project DIRECT, in particular its tool dphon, is designed to offer new avenues for research, as it approaches the problem of parallel text by means of a grapheme-to-phoneme (G2P) conversion. This open-access project hence enables users to quickly and easily search for parallel passages in texts on the basis of their general phonological features, which allows users to identify homophonous and near-homophonous passages across different texts that may be obscured by a purely grapheme-based search. Intratextually, this also allows for an identification of linguistic devices such as rhymes, puns, and rhetorical constructions which also build primarily on the phonological properties rather than the written representation thereof. We will demonstrate the capabilities of DIRECT’s current version, the general structure of this tool, and the intended future directions of the project.

DIRECT is the product of an ongoing collaboration between Gian Rominger and John O’Leary, both Ph.D. students in East Asian Studies, and Digital Humanities Developer Nick Budak. The project seeks to offer researchers free and open-source tools for Old Chinese natural language processing, and is participating in the National Endowment for the Humanities’ New Languages for NLP grant in 2021.

content.$t: Virtual Citizenship: Exploring Immigrant Literature through Extended Reality

gs$cell.inputValue: Virtual Citizenship: Exploring Immigrant Literature through Extended Reality
gs$cell.$t: Virtual Citizenship: Exploring Immigrant Literature through Extended Reality

content.$t: This presentation will detail a grant-funded project intended to thoughtfully and ethically integrate Extended Reality (XR) technology across the curriculum. Born out of this project is a first-year literature course, certified as fulfilling “Intercultural Knowledge Competency” (IKC), focused on literature written by and about those seeking citizenship in the United States. The students in the course consider poetry, short stories, novels, and cultural objects such as music videos, viral content, and news publications as well as Virtual Reality applications that raise questions about the language and imagery used to define immigrants, refugees, and asylum seekers.Using narrative as a means of cultivating empathy, and service learning partnerships to encourage long-term action, this course employs what Lisa Blankenship coined “rhetorical empathy” to structure research and reflection. The introduction and critique of the VR applications is intended to test the hypothesis that immersive experiences can teach empathy, a premise currently under debate in both the humanities and social sciences. In considering the criticism of scholars such as Lisa Nakamura and Liz Losh alongside the advocacy of artists such as Chris Milk and Gabo Aurora, the speaker will demonstrate ways of pairing XR content with traditional creative and academic texts to provoke respectful conversation, sustained service and activism within the community, and multimodal research projects. The presenter will showcase assignments and examples of student work, as well as inviting the audience to experience the VR applications utilized in the class. This radical approach to teaching literature leads to radical student work that is student-led and community-engaged.

content.$t: Langston Hughes, Text Encoding, and Black DH for Undergraduates

gs$cell.inputValue: Langston Hughes, Text Encoding, and Black DH for Undergraduates
gs$cell.$t: Langston Hughes, Text Encoding, and Black DH for Undergraduates

content.$t:
Langston Hughes's works, in the public domain since 2017, provide a wonderful resource for students learning textual curation. From the start of the fall 2020 Text Encoding class at Penn State Erie, the class worked with digital facsimiles of Hughes's short manuscripts to experiment with encoding text structures and metadata in their first experience with eXtensible Markup Languages (XML). Before they learned about the Text Encoding Initiative (TEI), the students were assigned to define their own rules for encoding marks on facsimile page surfaces, and the handwriting inserted in typescript poems. In the second half of the course, as students learned HTML, XPath, and XSLT (used for transforming XML to other formats like HTML), they were assigned to develop small-scale digital editions hosted on GitHub from a set of options selected by Dr. Beshero-Bondar ([see https://newtfire.org/courses/textEncoding/projectOptions-2020.html](https://newtfire.org/courses/textEncoding/projectOptions-2020.html)). Especially since we were away from campus archives during the pandemic, we needed legible online facsimiles as an "on-ramp" for students without much experience with reading cursive handwriting. Those materials also needed to raise provocative questions, to "hook" students into close analysis and contextual research. Hughes's digitized typescripts available through Yale's Beinecke Library were among the most inviting for our students. 
Mia Borgia led a project on Hughes' play of 1956, "The Ballot and Me," dramatizing a history of black voting rights in the U.S. She and her team decided not only on the markup rules for her project, but also how to design an edition interface with alternative ways to read and enter the play. For example, Borgia prepared XSLT to feature each historical character in a searchable sorted index together with their longest speeches: https://am0eba-byte.github.io/BallotandMe/analysis.html. For this talk, Beshero-Bondar will discuss how she developed the project assignment, and Borgia will address the intellectual process of designing her own project. Together we hope to demonstrate the importance of giving undergraduates the independent lead roles in designing small-scale digital editions as a first experience with serious scholarship and public humanities

content.$t: What Can An Essay Compute? Case Study in Critical DH Pedagogy

gs$cell.inputValue: What Can An Essay Compute? Case Study in Critical DH Pedagogy
gs$cell.$t: What Can An Essay Compute? Case Study in Critical DH Pedagogy

content.$t:
Our paper engages issues of critical practice and experimental pedagogy, starting from an undergraduate fellowship based in the library now in its sixth year. Our questions are not new to co-curricular digital humanities instruction. How to open up spaces and discourses to diverse students who have largely not been included until recently? How to explore both technical artifacts and skills alongside conceptual tools and methods gleaned from affiliated disciplines? Taking a cue from “What is a computational essay?”, Stephen Wolfram’s 2017 provocative blog post, we generated our own Computational Essays, interrogating and defining just what that might mean along the way.

The resulting projects make use of Observable, a new JavaScript notebook platform, and are inspired as much by code studies as by the code notebooks prevalent in science pedagogy, not to mention Miriam Posner’s well-documented digital humanities capstone assignment. The Computational Essay here serves as a central, flexible tool intermingling code and prose, a single artifact in which HTML text, executable scripts, and their outputs appear without apparent hierarchy privileging one over the other.

Students had the semester to consider a topic of interest and find a corresponding dataset, and through trial and error, engage both visual and discursive narratives “in” the data as well as observations “about” the data. Shuttling between issues of representation, standards, infrastructure, code, and rhetoric, students had the opportunity to wrestle with major themes of the fellowship. Our paper will outline our approach and explore the ways the Computational Essay might be used as a critical, playful mode of encountering code.

content.$t: Since the advent of the printing press, bookplates have been used to mark the ownership of texts, signal characteristics of their proprietor, and stand as works of graphic art and design in their own right. The study and collecting of bookplates, also known as ex libris, blossomed in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. This period saw the advent of the Ex Libris Society and its associated journal, as well as numerous publications aiding in the study and identification of bookplates. Much in the same ways ex libris fascinated turn-of-the century bibliophiles, bookplates now reside in many institutional special collections and serve as research material for the lay enthusiast and scholar alike. In applying new computational methodologies to this centuries-old tradition, this project uses visualization methods as well as image analysis techniques to detect and match bookplates in a large corpus of page images. In order to test the accuracy of the image analysis techniques, this project include in its dataset, titles featuring the bookplates of the Novecento architect Giovanni Muzio which appear in several early works on architecture in various states (with and without text, overlapping with other bookplates, and half ripped). Much in the way that art history and digital initiatives have used image analysis to consolidate and correlate photo archives images, this dataset could also help test the feasibility of similar applications to bookplates. This could also demonstrate the application of computer vision to the non-consumptive exploration of visual content, enhances scholarly access to a resource with limited discoverability, and surfaces potential research opportunities/connections between bibliography, history of reading, book history, graphic arts, and beyond.

content.$t: A Challenge in Document Data Modeling: Anna Julia Cooper's Responses to the Survey of Negro College Graduates

gs$cell.inputValue: A Challenge in Document Data Modeling: Anna Julia Cooper's Responses to the Survey of Negro College Graduates
gs$cell.$t: A Challenge in Document Data Modeling: Anna Julia Cooper's Responses to the Survey of Negro College Graduates

content.$t:
In the 1930s, Dr. Anna Julia Cooper, renowned educator and foremother of Black feminist thought, responded to a Survey of Negro College Graduates. Cooper's response to one question about her "racial philosophy" exceeded the limits of the form and was later published as an essay, removed from its original context. Preparing a [digital scholarly edition of the document](https://alicer98.github.io/DIGIT-110-AJC-Survey/document.html) poses a distinct challenge to juxtapose a typescript form with handwritten input, a scenario not currently modeled in the Text Encoding Initiative (TEI) Guidelines. The document represents a back-and-forth between two voices—the typescript questions and the handwritten responses—and yet it is also a primary source in the form of a manuscript composed on a printed, circulated document. 
Guided by Shirley Moody-Turner, who partnered with the Moorland-Spingarn Research Center to digitize [Cooper's collection at Howard University](https://dh.howard.edu/ajcooper/), Elisa Beshero-Bondar's Text Encoding class encoded the survey as a document data modeling challenge. Alice Rong's ideas for working with the TEI guided Beshero-Bondar to develop a TEI ODD for handwriting on a [printed form](https://github.com/AliceR98/DIGIT-110-AJC-Survey/blob/main/TEI-ODD-AJC/AJCSurvey-ODD.odd). Rong led the project to encode the survey and transform it with XSLT to optimize the writing for web reading and searching of historical data. The project, viewable at [https://alicer98.github.io/DIGIT-110-AJC-Survey/AJC-output.html](https://alicer98.github.io/DIGIT-110-AJC-Survey/AJC-output.html), contributes a significant new approach to modeling the document structures of primary sources that enmesh print with handwriting, with both equivalently important. Our collaboration highlights the importance of digital scholarly editing for Black digital humanities research that involves undergraduates with faculty scholars in making resources legible and findable.

content.$t: A Challenge in Document Data Modeling: Anna Julia Cooper's Responses to the Survey of Negro College Graduates

gs$cell.inputValue: A Challenge in Document Data Modeling: Anna Julia Cooper's Responses to the Survey of Negro College Graduates
gs$cell.$t: A Challenge in Document Data Modeling: Anna Julia Cooper's Responses to the Survey of Negro College Graduates

content.$t:
In the 1930s, Dr. Anna Julia Cooper, renowned educator and foremother of Black feminist thought, responded to a Survey of Negro College Graduates. Cooper's response to one question about her "racial philosophy" exceeded the limits of the form and was later published as an essay, removed from its original context. Preparing a [digital scholarly edition of the document](https://alicer98.github.io/DIGIT-110-AJC-Survey/document.html) poses a distinct challenge to juxtapose a typescript form with handwritten input, a scenario not currently modeled in the Text Encoding Initiative (TEI) Guidelines. The document represents a back-and-forth between two voices—the typescript questions and the handwritten responses—and yet it is also a primary source in the form of a manuscript composed on a printed, circulated document. 
Guided by Shirley Moody-Turner, who partnered with the Moorland-Spingarn Research Center to digitize [Cooper's collection at Howard University](https://dh.howard.edu/ajcooper/), Elisa Beshero-Bondar's Text Encoding class encoded the survey as a document data modeling challenge. Alice Rong's ideas for working with the TEI guided Beshero-Bondar to develop a TEI ODD for handwriting on a [printed form](https://github.com/AliceR98/DIGIT-110-AJC-Survey/blob/main/TEI-ODD-AJC/AJCSurvey-ODD.odd). Rong led the project to encode the survey and transform it with XSLT to optimize the writing for web reading and searching of historical data. The project, viewable at [https://alicer98.github.io/DIGIT-110-AJC-Survey/AJC-output.html](https://alicer98.github.io/DIGIT-110-AJC-Survey/AJC-output.html), contributes a significant new approach to modeling the document structures of primary sources that enmesh print with handwriting, with both equivalently important. Our collaboration highlights the importance of digital scholarly editing for Black digital humanities research that involves undergraduates with faculty scholars in making resources legible and findable.

content.$t: A Community-Based Approach to Incorporating the Digital Humanities into Graduate Education

gs$cell.inputValue: A Community-Based Approach to Incorporating the Digital Humanities into Graduate Education
gs$cell.$t: A Community-Based Approach to Incorporating the Digital Humanities into Graduate Education

content.$t: Many graduate students who enter the field of Digital Humanities need to balance the commitment necessary to learn new skill sets with existing responsibilities in their respective fields and personal lives. How should one decide what is worth the time investment with an eye towards the larger goals of graduate education? This panel assembles graduate students who have begun to incorporate DH to address research-specific questions and pedagogical issues. The three graduate student panelists and their post-graduate mentor met as fellows at Princeton University’s Center for Digital Humanities, and as a cohort have been communicating virtually to discuss how best to use DH to ask questions with data as well as how to apply tools for enhanced storytelling in their research and the classroom. Despite their diverse projects, material, and disciplines, the panelists have found community and dialogue essential throughout the iterative process, not only for progressing and problem-solving in their research but also for addressing shared methodological concerns in organization, analysis, and teaching with large-scale datasets.

content.$t: Roman Street Shrines: Virtual and Geographic Analyses of Urban Devotion

gs$cell.inputValue: Roman Street Shrines: Virtual and Geographic Analyses of Urban Devotion
gs$cell.$t: Roman Street Shrines: Virtual and Geographic Analyses of Urban Devotion

content.$t: Louis Hamilton, Albert Dorman Honors College, NJIT

gs$cell.inputValue: Louis Hamilton, Albert Dorman Honors College, NJIT
gs$cell.$t: Louis Hamilton, Albert Dorman Honors College, NJIT

content.$t: This panel presents the work of the Digital Spatial History Lab on the edicole sacre (street shrines) of Rome. Working with undergraduate researchers for the past decade, the group has built what is believed to be the largest geographic database of the street shrines in Rome. Pioneering the social and anthropological analysis of urban religious devotion through the use of GIS and VR, the lab’s current team of undergraduate researchers and one of the directors, offer five presentations on the project. 1) The Street Shrines of Rome Project: History and Method offers an overview of the project, using GIS to reconsider the origins of the shrines, their transformation over time to the present. 2) Building an Ontological Database describes the taxonomy created using WebProtégé, opening up the possibility to more precise analysis. 3) Measuring Mass Tourism’s Affect on Religious Devotion suggests the capabilities of this analysis to answer one of the most urgent questions for cultural heritage sites in the present. 4) Reconstructing and Deconstructing Rome’s Grottapinta Shrine, a VR Model describes the methods used to create 3D and VR models of one shrine to test how individuals experience this as (or not) as visual input. 5) Next steps: from Roman Streets to Big Data considers the next steps for the project as we shift to a MySQL database and create a new user interface. Panel Participants: Dr. Louis Hamilton, PI, History, Honors College Elizabeth Kowalchuck, ‘23 Xavier Reyes, ‘22 Mary Riccio, ‘23 Noah Roselli, ‘22 Meredith Westrich, ‘24 Co-PI’s (not presenting): Dr. Vincent Oria, Computer Science Dr. Burcak Ozludil, Honors College, Co-Director, Digital Spatial History Lab Dr. Rita Vinnakov, Informatics

content.$t: Roundtable on Collaborative Use of Historical Police Records

gs$cell.inputValue: Roundtable on Collaborative Use of Historical Police Records
gs$cell.$t: Roundtable on Collaborative Use of Historical Police Records

content.$t: In 2019, the Lehigh University Libraries Special Collections received a donation from the Bethlehem Police Department of over 700 police record books dating from 1916 to 1952. Since receipt of this collection, Special Collections work-study student assistants have been engaged in the processing, digitization, and transcription of these records. Under the supervision of Lehigh’s Digital Archivist, student assistants have digitized over fifty volumes of historical police records since August 2020. With Lehigh’s transition to virtual instruction in March 2020, transcription of these volumes has been a crucial part of students’ remote work. Using Google Drive, eight students have transcribed over 30 volumes and made thousands of arrest records readable and searchable in spreadsheets. Work-study students have also been working to normalize data contained within these records in order to produce a visualization using GIS software. Students will also assist in the creation of descriptive metadata to facilitate the ingestion of digitized police records into Lehigh’s Digital Collections repository, where they will be made accessible to the public. These records have also been used for primary source instruction in the course “History 090: Prisons and Policing in Modern U.S. History,” taught by Dr. Emily Pope-Obeda. This virtual instruction session used the police records to elucidate the history that led to the contemporary system of policing in America. In particular, this class session focused on representations of race, mental illness, and public health documented in these records and how the criminalization of certain activities has changed over time. This panel will consist of Digital Archivist Alex Japha, Assistant Professor of History Dr. Emily Pope-Obeda, and a Special Collections work study student. The panel will address the technical and ethical challenges of collecting, preserving, and making accessible historical police records along with the potential for research and teaching opportunities in this genre.

Work-study students have also been working to normalize data contained within these records in order to produce a visualization using GIS software. Students will also assist in the creation of descriptive metadata to facilitate the ingestion of digitized police records into Lehigh’s Digital Collections repository, where they will be made accessible to the public. These records have also been used for primary source instruction in the course “History 090: Prisons and Policing in Modern U.S. History,” taught by Dr. Emily Pope-Obeda. This virtual instruction session used the police records to elucidate the history that led to the contemporary system of policing in America. In particular, this class session focused on representations of race, mental illness, and public health documented in these records and how the criminalization of certain activities has changed over time. This panel will consist of Digital Archivist Alex Japha, Assistant Professor of History Dr. Emily Pope-Obeda, and a Special Collections work study student. The panel will address the technical and ethical challenges of collecting, preserving, and making accessible historical police records along with the potential for research and teaching opportunities in this genre.

content.$t: The Unincorporated Frontier: Creative Writing in the Digital Humanities

gs$cell.inputValue: The Unincorporated Frontier: Creative Writing in the Digital Humanities
gs$cell.$t: The Unincorporated Frontier: Creative Writing in the Digital Humanities

content.$t: Humanities classrooms are incorporating more technology as the demand for digital classrooms and distance learning opportunities continues to grow. However, creative writing, one of the most popular majors in the humanities, which has shown a 130 % growth in undergraduate majors over the last 10 years, has remained largely resistant to this wave of change. This panel will provide examples of the ways in which a variety of digital materials can be successfully incorporated into the creative writing classroom. We will also discuss the difficulties as well as the benefits of teaching creative writing online, generate methods of building a successful digital writing curriculum, and illustrate the ways in which incorporating technology into the traditional writing workshop model can connect with a more diverse number of learning styles. Creative writing classrooms are one of the last untapped frontiers of the digital humanities, and this panel will provide valuable insight into the ways in which this popular major is prime for more digital applications.

content.$t: Black Artist Data Curation through Wikidata

gs$cell.inputValue: Black Artist Data Curation through Wikidata
gs$cell.$t: Black Artist Data Curation through Wikidata

content.$t: The Wikidata project helps to ensure digital visibility for Black artists in the Philadelphia Museum of Art collection, library, and archives and Temple's Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection. Specifically, I am researching missing information and blogging about each artist to serve as the reference URL for their Wikidata entry. This work is also being used as a case study to support the work being done for PMA's Art Information Commons to develop methods to link artwork to contextual information (e.g. archival records and bibliographic records).

content.$t: Revolutionary City: Digital Recovery of Underrepresented Voices in the Archive

gs$cell.inputValue: Revolutionary City: Digital Recovery of Underrepresented Voices in the Archive
gs$cell.$t: Revolutionary City: Digital Recovery of Underrepresented Voices in the Archive

content.$t: A challenge to the important work of recovering the underrepresented voices of the American Revolution is the organization of the archive. For the Revolutionary period, archival collections tend to be organized around elite white men, subordinating the voices of women, African Americans, Loyalists, and Native Americans contained within. The stories are there, but accessing them can be difficult for those without the resources or training to know how to find them. An Institute for Museum and Library Services (IMLS) National Leadership Grants for Libraries award provided an opportunity to explore how to make the manuscript and broadside archives of the American Philosophical Society, the Historical Society of Pennsylvania, and the Library Company of Philadelphia accessible through a digital portal. “Revolutionary City: A Portal to the Nation’s Founding” seeks to center underrepresented voices from Philadelphia during the Revolutionary period (May 1774 - September 1783) by engaging a stakeholder committee of 16 educators, archivists, and scholars to meet bimonthly to identify missing or overlooked narratives of the Revolution; to review existing metadata on archival collections; to propose metadata standards carefully designed to make accessible a broader range of voices; and to design a digital portal which serves as a platform for discovery, contextualization, and education about the American Revolution. This paper will reflect on the process of working with stakeholders to create this new portal, share the discoveries available through it, and demonstrate the interface for feedback from conference attendees.

content.$t:
The field of authorship attribution pertains to identifying the author of an anonymous document from a pool of potential authors. This field has many practical applications, from historical literature to forensic linguistics. Over the past few decades, a huge amount of work has been done regarding authorship attribution for commonly-spoken languages such as English, Spanish, Mandarin, etc. Unfortunately, the potential for authorship attribution in less-commonly spoken languages, such as those in Southeast Asia, has gone unrealized. 
A member of the Austroasiatic language family, Khmer is spoken by 18 million people, most of which are Cambodian (Ebenhard et al. 2021). Despite this sizable speaker base and rich literary history, no significant advances have yet been made for Khmer stylometry. This is partially because many authorship attribution techniques (and those of quantitative authorship attribution in particular) were specifically designed for English and other commonly-spoken languages. However, after several hundred preliminary experiments, some pre-existing stylometric software has shown potential to be an accurate tool for doing authorship attribution in Khmer and related languages. Using the Java Graphical Authorship Attribution Program, or JGAAP (Juola 2009), we compared 200 Khmer documents across 20 unique authors. While we observed marginal success across many different settings, the N-grams setting (Juola 2006) had the highest accuracy rate by far. While presenting our findings, we will also explore the nature of written Khmer to explain why this particular setting is so successful. Finally, we will conclude with some discussion on the relevance of this work and potential for further studies in the future. 
Eberhard, David M., Gary F. Simons, and Charles D. Fennig (eds.). 2021. Ethnologue: Languages of the World. Twenty-fourth edition. Dallas, Texas: SIL International. Online version: http://www.ethnologue.com.
Juola, Patrick. 2006. Authorship Attribution. In Foundations and Trends in Information Retrieval, Volume 1, Number 3. 
Juola, Patrick. 2009. JGAAP: A System for Comparative Evaluation of Authorship Attribution. In Division of the Humanities at University of Chicago.

content.$t: Twitter Literature: Analyzing and Reflecting on Twitter’s Poetry Community

gs$cell.inputValue: Twitter Literature: Analyzing and Reflecting on Twitter’s Poetry Community
gs$cell.$t: Twitter Literature: Analyzing and Reflecting on Twitter’s Poetry Community

content.$t: With 500 million daily tweets, Twitter is one of the most frequented social media platforms in the world, and as such, it is well positioned to be a magnet for grassroots poetry. This paper seeks to understand the role of Twitter as a dominant platform for poets commenting on topics ranging from their current social climate to individual artistic expression. In fact, scholars such as Seth Perlow and Brownen Thomas have studied the growth, popularity, and accessibility of social media – including Instagram and Twitter – as a platform for amateur poets. Such scholarship is further advanced by Project Twitter Literature (TwitLit), a Digital Humanities research project focused on understanding how Twitter acts as a platform for literary publication, discussion, and distribution. Using data collected by Project TwitLit, this paper examines tweets categorized by poetic hashtags in order to analyze the transient subject matter of this amateur poetry. Methodologically, we used natural language processing techniques and machine learning classification models in order to collect multiple metrics related to this body of literature, including a comprehensive grid search to create topic models for each literary category and date, the topic’s place in time and location, and statistics on tweet interaction. This computational analysis has revealed that, while some common themes have never strayed from the minds of amateur poets, poetry on Twitter both echoes and advances prevailing political and social discourse. The tools developed as part of this project are open source and [available on GitHub](https://github.com/TwitLit/TwitLitSource).

content.$t: The Intersectional Implications of Youtube Bigotry: A Digital Analysis of Commenter Reactions to Two-spirit and Non-Native Queer Identities

gs$cell.inputValue: The Intersectional Implications of Youtube Bigotry: A Digital Analysis of Commenter Reactions to Two-spirit and Non-Native Queer Identities
gs$cell.$t: The Intersectional Implications of Youtube Bigotry: A Digital Analysis of Commenter Reactions to Two-spirit and Non-Native Queer Identities

content.$t: Two-spirit, coined in 1990 at the third annual Native American/First Nations gay and lesbian conference in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada, is defined by Kylan Mattias de Vries’ article in the Encyclopedia of Gender and Society, “serves as a self-identifying term in place of Western concepts and identifies such as gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender, intersex, queer, cross-dresser, and so on” for many Indigenous people in North America. It is an identity that inherently exists on the margins, encompassing queerness and racial/ethnic experience different than white queer identity. Through digital analysis, I wanted to investigate the discussion of LGBT identity of both Indigenous and non-Native people and what textual analysis can reveal; what language do people use in response to these topics? What is the intent behind the language? How do people respond to queer identity under colonialism compared to a decolonized approach of queerness, and why? To do this, I used a YouTube data tool to scrape comments from videos that I cleaned into two corpuses, one of comments of videos related to two-spirit identity and the other relating to non-Native queer identity, to analyze through spreadsheet manipulation, AntConc, Voyant, and Topic Modeling Tool. In analyzing different aspects of negative comments, such as frequency and diction, I was able to conclude that hostility in the white queer identity corpus related to sexuality and gender identity, whereas backlash in the two-spirit identity corpus targeted racial identity through a homophobic or transphobic lens, such as an individual being “white passing” or “too masculine” to be two-spirit. Although my research and analysis look at over one thousand comments per corpus, a relatively small amount of data, the way in which people respond online can be a microcosm of bigotry in other spheres. Looking at these comments is important for an intersectional understanding of marginalized experiences

content.$t: The Challenges of Email Appraisal and Archiving: A Case Study

gs$cell.inputValue: The Challenges of Email Appraisal and Archiving: A Case Study
gs$cell.$t: The Challenges of Email Appraisal and Archiving: A Case Study

content.$t:
In this presentation, we will share our critical assessment of the process of appraising email for the creation of digital archives. As the Council on Library and Information Resources’ recent report on email archiving highlights (footnote), email has increasingly become an essential part of the historical record, yet it presents a series of unique challenges for preservation. Our work originates from a year-long class project dedicated to assisting A&SC with the development of workflows for email archiving. Building on our experiences with the Department of Archives & Special Collections (A&SC) at the University of Pittsburgh and on interviews with several digital archivists, we will review the different aspects involved in preparing for email preservation at a research university. In particular, we will discuss the privacy and legal concerns raised by email archiving and examine the process of appraisal through ePADD. This open-source software relies on natural language processing and other computational analytic methods to evaluate the different parts of email, including correspondents, headers, attachments, and sensitive data. 
We will explore the following questions: how is value determined when we are preserving email, especially for research in the humanities? What kinds of data should be included when we are appraising email? How can this process be automated and how can tools like ePADD assist us? What are the implications of automating these practices?

content.$t: Digital Storytelling as Community- Created Knowledge

gs$cell.inputValue: Digital Storytelling as Community- Created Knowledge
gs$cell.$t: Digital Storytelling as Community- Created Knowledge

content.$t: Digital storytelling appears to hold promise as a progressive, critical method for the collection, preservation, and dissemination of “community-created knowledge”, particularly among communities historically silenced, ignored or ‘spoken about’ by the media, political officials and academics. While much attention has been paid to the practical and technical dimensions of digital storytelling, less is known about the collective experience of creating and sharing digital stories among storytellers themselves. This presentation features a panel of four storytellers from Chester Digital Storytelling, a community-based humanities initiative in Chester -- Pennsylvania’s poorest city in the state’s wealthiest county. The panelists -- all residents of Chester - will speak of their direct experiences with sharing their stories, the lessons they have learned through the process of creating stories, their growing proficiency with digital technologies, and their expectations for how storytelling can build cultural power and take back the narrative about their city and its residents.

content.$t: Photogrammetry and Community Engagement with Heritage Sites

gs$cell.inputValue: Photogrammetry and Community Engagement with Heritage Sites
gs$cell.$t: Photogrammetry and Community Engagement with Heritage Sites

content.$t: This presentation explores the application of photogrammetry and hosting digital assets online for purposes of preservation, accessibility and, most importantly, community engagement with heritage. I will discuss my experiences of employing photogrammetry as a method for building community engagement with archaeological and other heritage sites during the covid-19 pandemic. This presentation is in dialogue with public archaeology scholarship such as Atalay’s Community-Based Archaeological Research model and explores the ways in which digital humanity techniques such as photogrammetry enables community building and engagement at every stage of the process from taking photos to hosting them online. The presentation will also discuss the ethical considerations of creating and sharing digital heritage objects.

content.$t: Micro-Culture to Mass Culture: Mapping the Birth of the American Entertainment Industry

gs$cell.inputValue: Micro-Culture to Mass Culture: Mapping the Birth of the American Entertainment Industry
gs$cell.$t: Micro-Culture to Mass Culture: Mapping the Birth of the American Entertainment Industry

content.$t:
During the late 19th and early 20th centuries, the United States saw a massive expansion of popular entertainment. Produced by highly capitalized firms working out of cultural centers like New York and Los Angeles, troupes of performers moved through a continent increasingly connected by rail, road, and telegraph, exploiting new forms of media and advertising in order to attract vast audiences to their popularly-priced commercial leisure. While organized in major cities, the majority of the audience for these shows was drawn from hundreds of small towns and cities across the country. 
Developed in conjunction with a course taught at Johns Hopkins University, and created with the support of a University Technology Fellowship, Entertaining America used ArcGIS mapping to recreate the true diversity of popular entertainment during the late 19th century.  Examining a set of 15 small towns throughout the United States over the period between 1860 and 1930, the project used digitized, key-word searchable newspapers to create a database of performances, venues, and artists, which were then mapped against the historical layout of the towns in which they occurred, relying on georeferenced Sanborn fire insurance maps to provide detailed geographic information. The results of the project tell a remarkably nuanced story. Far from overwhelming local entertainment forms, the introduction of a national commercial culture coexisted with its smaller-scale counterparts for decades, reshaping the references and conditions of local performance while providing it with new avenues to flourish. 
By incorporating students directly into the process of primary source collection and analysis, the collaborative digital methods employed by Entertaining America provided a venue for undergraduates to grapple with intellectual, philosophical, and emotional challenges of historical inquiry.  In doing so, Entertaining America not only created a body of useful historical data, but provides a potential blueprint for future digital history classes and projects.

Produced by highly capitalized firms working out of cultural centers like New York and Los Angeles, troupes of performers moved through a continent increasingly connected by rail, road, and telegraph, exploiting new forms of media and advertising in order to attract vast audiences to their popularly-priced commercial leisure. While organized in major cities, the majority of the audience for these shows was drawn from hundreds of small towns and cities across the country. 
Developed in conjunction with a course taught at Johns Hopkins University, and created with the support of a University Technology Fellowship, Entertaining America used ArcGIS mapping to recreate the true diversity of popular entertainment during the late 19th century.  Examining a set of 15 small towns throughout the United States over the period between 1860 and 1930, the project used digitized, key-word searchable newspapers to create a database of performances, venues, and artists, which were then mapped against the historical layout of the towns in which they occurred, relying on georeferenced Sanborn fire insurance maps to provide detailed geographic information. The results of the project tell a remarkably nuanced story. Far from overwhelming local entertainment forms, the introduction of a national commercial culture coexisted with its smaller-scale counterparts for decades, reshaping the references and conditions of local performance while providing it with new avenues to flourish. 
By incorporating students directly into the process of primary source collection and analysis, the collaborative digital methods employed by Entertaining America provided a venue for undergraduates to grapple with intellectual, philosophical, and emotional challenges of historical inquiry.  In doing so, Entertaining America not only created a body of useful historical data, but provides a potential blueprint for future digital history classes and projects.

content.$t: We propose a “campfire” session exploring opportunities in the rich data created by [In Her Own Right](http://inherownright.org), a Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries project that has digitized, cataloged, and contextualized thousands of letters, diaries, meeting minutes, and photographs that tell the story of women’s activism, 1820-1920, through the holdings of 20 archives. Our 10,000+ record custom dataset is available via API to explore the contours of women’s activism at scale. Through a presentation of three use cases for In Her Own Right data, this session will explore the opportunities and responsibilities of approaching collections related to women’s history as data.
